column2: THE WONDERS OF TERRESTRIAL DEPTHS

column2: At eight in the morning a ray of daylight came to wake us up.

column2: Well, Axel, what do you say to it? cried my uncle, rubbing his hands.

column2: No noise of cart wheels, no cries of basket women, no boatmen shouting!"

column2: Now come! my uncle cried; "if you are frightened already, what will you be by and by?
column3: Now come! my uncle cried; "if you are frightened already, what will you be by and by?

column2: We have not gone a single inch yet into the bowels of the earth."
column3: We have not gone a single inch yet into the bowels of the earth."

column2: What do you mean?
column3: What do you mean?

column2: I mean that we have only reached the level of the island, long vertical tube, which terminates at the mouth of the crater, has its lower end only at the level of the sea.
column3: I mean that we have only reached the level of the island, long vertical tube, which terminates at the mouth of the crater, has its lower end only at the level of the sea.

column2: Are you sure of that?
column3: Are you sure of that?

column2: Quite sure.	Quite sure.

column2: Consult the barometer."
column3: Consult the barometer."

column2: In fact, the mercury, which had risen in the instrument as fast as we descended, had stopped at twenty-nine inches.
column3: In fact, the mercury, which had risen in the instrument as fast as we descended, had stopped at twenty nine inches.

column2: You see, said the Professor, "we have now only the pressure of our atmosphere, and I shall be glad when the aneroid takes the place of the barometer."
column3: You see, said the Professor, "we have now only the pressure of our atmosphere, and I shall be glad when the aneroid takes the place of the barometer."

column2: And in truth this instrument would become useless as soon as the weight of the atmosphere should exceed the pressure ascertained at the level of the sea.
column3: And in truth this instrument would become useless as soon as the weight of the atmosphere should exceed the pressure ascertained at the level of the sea.

column2: But, I said, "is there not reason to fear that this ever-increasing pressure will become at last very painful to bear?"
column3: But, I said, "is there not reason to fear that this ever increasing pressure will become at last very painful to bear?"

column2: No; we shall descend at a slow rate, and our lungs will become inured to a denser atmosphere.	No; we shall descend at a slow rate, and our lungs will become inured to a denser atmosphere.

column2: Aeronauts find the want of air as they rise to high elevations, but we shall perhaps have too much: of the two, this is what I should prefer.

column2: Don't let us lose a moment.

column2: The bundle had been caught by a projection a hundred feet above us.

column2: Now, said my uncle, "let us breakfast; but we must lay in a good stock, for we don't know how long we may have to go on."
column3: Now, said my uncle, "let us breakfast; but we must lay in a good stock, for we don't know how long we may have to go on."

column2: Now, Axel, cried the Professor with enthusiasm, "now we are really going into the interior of the earth.
column3: Now, Axel, cried the Professor with enthusiasm, "now we are really going into the interior of the earth.

column2: At this precise moment the journey commences."
column3: At this precise moment the journey commences."

column2: So saying, my uncle took in one hand Ruhmkorff's apparatus, which was hanging from his neck; and with the other he formed an electric communication with the coil in the lantern, and a sufficiently bright light dispersed the darkness of the passage.
column3: So saying, my uncle took in one hand Ruhmkorff's apparatus, which was hanging from his neck; and with the other he formed an electric communication with the coil in the lantern, and a sufficiently bright light dispersed the darkness of the passage.

column2: Hans carried the other apparatus, which was also put into action. This ingenious application of electricity would enable us to go on for a long time by creating an artificial light even in the midst of the most inflammable gases.
column3: Hans carried the other apparatus, which was also put into action. This ingenious application of electricity would enable us to go on for a long time by creating an artificial light even in the midst of the most inflammable gases.

column2: Now, march! cried my uncle.
column3: Now, march! cried my uncle.

column2: Hans drove before him the load of cords and clothes; and, myself walking last, we entered the gallery.
column3: Hans drove before him the load of cords and clothes; and, myself walking last, we entered the gallery.

column2: At the moment of becoming engulfed in this dark gallery, I raised my head, and saw for the last time through the length of that vast tube the sky of Iceland, which I was never to behold again.

column2: The only difficulty in proceeding lay in not sliding too fast down an incline of about forty-five degrees; happily certain asperities and a few blisterings here and there formed steps, and we descended, letting our baggage slip before us from the end of a long rope.
column3: The only difficulty in proceeding lay in not sliding too fast down an incline of about forty five degrees; happily certain asperities and a few blisterings here and there formed steps, and we descended, letting our baggage slip before us from the end of a long rope.

column2: But that which formed steps under our feet became stalactites overhead.
column3: But that which formed steps under our feet became stalactites overhead.

column2: The lava, which was porous in many places, had formed a surface covered with small rounded blisters; crystals of opaque quartz, set with limpid tears of glass, and hanging like clustered chandeliers from the vaulted roof, seemed as it were to kindle and form a sudden illumination as we passed on our way.
column3: The lava, which was porous in many places, had formed a surface covered with small rounded blisters; crystals of opaque quartz, set with limpid tears of glass, and hanging like clustered chandeliers from the vaulted roof, seemed as it were to kindle and form a sudden illumination as we passed on our way.

column2: It seemed as if the genii of the depths were lighting up their palace to receive their terrestrial guests.
column3: It seemed as if the genii of the depths were lighting up their palace to receive their terrestrial guests.

column2: It is magnificent! I cried spontaneously.
column3: It is magnificent! I cried spontaneously.

column2: My uncle, what a sight! Don't you admire those blending hues of lava, passing from reddish brown to bright yellow by imperceptible shades?	My uncle, what a sight! Don't you admire those blending hues of lava, passing from reddish brown to bright yellow by imperceptible shades?
